code: chi_square(data, ..., weights = NULL, correct = FALSE)  phi(data, ..., weights = NULL, correct = FALSE)  cramers_v(data, ..., weights = NULL, correct = FALSE)  goodman_gamma(data, ..., weights = NULL, correct = FALSE)

title: Test If Two Categories Are Related — chi_square
text: data survey data (data frame tibble) ... Two categorical variables test (e.g., gender, region) weights Optional survey weights population-representative results correct Apply continuity correction small samples? (Default: FALSE)

title: Test If Two Categories Are Related — chi_square
text: Test results showing whether variables related, including: Chi-squared statistic p-value Observed vs expected frequencies Effect sizes measure relationship strength

title: Test If Two Categories Are Related — chi_square
text: P-value: p < 0.05, variables likely related (independent) p < 0.001: strong evidence relationship p < 0.01: Strong evidence relationship p < 0.05: Moderate evidence relationship p ≥ 0.05: significant relationship found Effect Sizes (strong relationship?): Cramer's V: Works table size (0 = relationship, 1 = perfect relationship) < 0.1: Negligible relationship 0.1-0.3: Small relationship 0.3-0.5: Medium relationship 0.5 higher: Large relationship Phi: 2x2 tables (similar interpretation Cramer's V) Gamma: ordinal data (-1 +1, shows direction relationship)

title: Test If Two Categories Are Related — chi_square
text: Use chi-squared test : variables categorical (gender, region, education level, etc.) want know related independent least 5 observations cells

title: Test If Two Categories Are Related — chi_square
text: Observed: actually found data Expected: expect variables independent Large differences suggest relationship exists

title: Test If Two Categories Are Related — chi_square
text: Check cells least 5 observations Use weights population estimates Look significance (p-value) strength (effect sizes) Consider using crosstab() detailed percentage breakdowns

title: Test If Two Categories Are Related — chi_square
code: # Load required packages and data library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union data(survey_data)  # Basic chi-squared test for independence survey_data %>% chi_square(gender, region) #>  #> ── Chi-Squared Test of Independence  ─────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Variables: gender x region #>  #> Observed Frequencies: #>         var2 #> var1     East West #>   Male    238  956 #>   Female  247 1059 #>  #> Expected Frequencies: #>         var2 #> var1        East     West #>   Male   231.636  962.364 #>   Female 253.364 1052.636 #>  #> Chi-Squared Test Results: #> --------------------------------------------------  #>  Chi_squared df p_value sig #>        0.415  1   0.519     #> --------------------------------------------------  #>  #> Effect Sizes: #> ----------------------------------------------------------------------  #>     Measure Value p_value sig Interpretation #>  Cramer's V 0.013   0.519            Neglig. #>         Phi 0.013   0.519            Neglig. #>       Gamma 0.033   0.659               Weak #> ----------------------------------------------------------------------  #> Table size: 2×2 | N = 2500 #>  #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05  # With weights survey_data %>% chi_square(gender, education, weights = sampling_weight) #>  #> ── Weighted Chi-Squared Test of Independence  ────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Variables: gender x education #> Weights variable: sampling_weight #>  #> Observed Frequencies: #>         var2 #> var1     Basic Secondary Intermediate Secondary Academic Secondary University #>   Male               402                    291                326        176 #>   Female             447                    350                316        209 #>  #> Expected Frequencies: #>         var2 #> var1     Basic Secondary Intermediate Secondary Academic Secondary University #>   Male           403.081                304.329            304.803    182.787 #>   Female         445.919                336.671            337.197    202.213 #>  #> Chi-Squared Test Results: #> --------------------------------------------------  #>  Chi_squared df p_value sig #>        4.403  3   0.221     #> --------------------------------------------------  #>  #> Effect Sizes: #> ----------------------------------------------------------------------  #>     Measure  Value p_value sig Interpretation #>  Cramer's V  0.042   0.221            Neglig. #>       Gamma -0.011   0.795               Weak #> ----------------------------------------------------------------------  #> Table size: 2×4 | N = 2517 #> Note: Phi coefficient only shown for 2x2 tables #>  #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05  # Grouped analysis survey_data %>%    group_by(region) %>%    chi_square(gender, employment) #>  #> ── Chi-Squared Test of Independence  ─────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Variables tested: gender x employment  #> Grouped by: region  #>  #> --- Group: region = East --- #>  #> Observed Frequencies: #>         var2 #> var1     Student Employed Unemployed Retired Other #>   Male         7      145         16      55    15 #>   Female       4      166         15      56     6 #>  #> Chi-Squared Test Results: #> --------------------------------------------------  #>  Chi_squared df p_value sig #>         5.97  4   0.201     #> --------------------------------------------------  #>  #> Effect Sizes: #> ----------------------------------------------------------------------  #>     Measure  Value p_value sig Interpretation #>  Cramer's V  0.111   0.201              Small #>       Gamma -0.093   0.468               Weak #> ----------------------------------------------------------------------  #> Table size: 2×5 | N = 485 #> Note: Phi coefficient only shown for 2x2 tables #>  #> --- Group: region = West --- #>  #> Observed Frequencies: #>         var2 #> var1     Student Employed Unemployed Retired Other #>   Male        29      605         68     201    53 #>   Female      38      684         83     213    41 #>  #> Chi-Squared Test Results: #> --------------------------------------------------  #>  Chi_squared df p_value sig #>        4.166  4   0.384     #> --------------------------------------------------  #>  #> Effect Sizes: #> ----------------------------------------------------------------------  #>     Measure  Value p_value sig Interpretation #>  Cramer's V  0.045   0.384            Neglig. #>       Gamma -0.053   0.381               Weak #> ----------------------------------------------------------------------  #> Table size: 2×5 | N = 2015 #> Note: Phi coefficient only shown for 2x2 tables #>  #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05  # With continuity correction survey_data %>% chi_square(gender, region, correct = TRUE) #>  #> ── Chi-Squared Test of Independence  ─────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Variables: gender x region #> Yates' continuity correction applied #>  #> Observed Frequencies: #>         var2 #> var1     East West #>   Male    238  956 #>   Female  247 1059 #>  #> Expected Frequencies: #>         var2 #> var1        East     West #>   Male   231.636  962.364 #>   Female 253.364 1052.636 #>  #> Chi-Squared Test Results: #> --------------------------------------------------  #>  Chi_squared df p_value sig #>        0.353  1   0.553     #> --------------------------------------------------  #>  #> Effect Sizes: #> ----------------------------------------------------------------------  #>     Measure Value p_value sig Interpretation #>  Cramer's V 0.012   0.553            Neglig. #>         Phi 0.012   0.553            Neglig. #>       Gamma 0.033   0.659               Weak #> ----------------------------------------------------------------------  #> Table size: 2×2 | N = 2500 #>  #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05

what: Compare Two Categories: See How They Relate — crosstab
title: Compare Two Categories: See How They Relate — crosstab
text: crosstab() shows two categorical variables relate . creates table reveals patterns - like whether education level differs region, gender influences product preferences. Think two-way frequency table shows: many people fall combination categories percentage cell represents Whether patterns associations

title: Compare Two Categories: See How They Relate — crosstab
code: crosstab(   data,   row,   col,   weights = NULL,   percentages = c("row", "none", "col", "total", "all"),   na.rm = TRUE,   digits = 1 )

title: Compare Two Categories: See How They Relate — crosstab
text: data survey data (data frame tibble) row variable table rows (e.g., education, age_group) col variable table columns (e.g., region, gender) weights Optional survey weights population-representative results percentages percentages show: "row" (default): Percentages across row (adds 100% horizontally) "col": Percentages column (adds 100% vertically) "total": Percentage entire table "": Show three types "none": Just counts, percentages na.rm Remove missing values? (Default: TRUE) digits Decimal places percentages (Default: 1)

title: Compare Two Categories: See How They Relate — crosstab
text: cross-tabulation table showing relationship two variables

title: Compare Two Categories: See How They Relate — crosstab
text: crosstab table shows: Cell counts: Number people combination Row %: Distribution within row (e.g., "Among high school education, X% live East") Column %: Distribution within column (e.g., "Among East, X% high school education") Total %: Percentage entire sample (e.g., "X% respondents high school education live East")

title: Compare Two Categories: See How They Relate — crosstab
text: Use crosstab want : See two categorical variables related Compare distributions across groups Find patterns survey responses Create demographic breakdowns

title: Get to Know Your Numeric Data — describe
text: describe() gives complete summary numeric variables - like age, income, satisfaction scores. first step analysis, helping understand typical, unusual, spread data . Think health check data reveals: average value? middle value? spread responses? unusual patterns outliers?

title: Get to Know Your Numeric Data — describe
code: describe(   data,   ...,   weights = NULL,   show = "short",   probs = c(0.25, 0.5, 0.75),   na.rm = TRUE,   excess = TRUE )

title: Get to Know Your Numeric Data — describe
text: data survey data (data frame tibble) ... numeric variables want summarize. List separated commas, use helpers like starts_with("trust") weights Optional survey weights get population-representative statistics. Without weights, describe sample. weights, describe population. show statistics display: "short" (default): Essential stats (mean, median, SD, range, IQR, skewness) "": Everything including variance, kurtosis, mode, quantiles Custom list: Choose specific stats like c("mean", "sd", "range") probs quantiles, percentiles show (default: 25th, 50th, 75th) na.rm Remove missing values calculating? (Default: TRUE) excess kurtosis, show excess kurtosis? (Default: TRUE, easier interpret)

title: Get to Know Your Numeric Data — describe
text: summary table descriptive statistics variable

title: Get to Know Your Numeric Data — describe
text: Key statistics tell : n: many valid responses (watch many missing) Mean: average value Median: middle value (half , half ) SD: Standard deviation - spread values Range: minimum maximum values IQR: Interquartile range - middle 50% values Skewness: Whether data leans left (negative) right (positive) Kurtosis: Whether unusual outliers

title: Get to Know Your Numeric Data — describe
text: Always start ! Use describe() : Check data quality (impossible values?) Understand distributions testing Spot outliers might affect analyses Compare groups side side

title: Get to Know Your Numeric Data — describe
text: Mean ≈ Median: Data roughly symmetric Mean > Median: Right-skewed (tail extends right) Mean < Median: Left-skewed (tail extends left) Large SD: Responses vary widely Small SD: Responses similar

title: Get to Know Your Numeric Data — describe
code: # Load required packages and data library(dplyr) data(survey_data)  # Basic unweighted analysis survey_data %>% describe(age) #>  #> ── Descriptive Statistics ────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  Variable  Mean Median     SD Range IQR Skewness    N Missing #>       age 50.55     50 16.976    77  24    0.172 2500       0 #> ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  # Weighted analysis survey_data %>% describe(age, weights = sampling_weight) #>  #> ── Weighted Descriptive Statistics ───────────────────────────────────────────── #>  Variable   Mean Median     SD Range IQR Skewness Effective_N #>       age 50.514     50 17.084    77  25    0.159      2468.8 #> ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  # Multiple variables with custom statistics survey_data %>% describe(age, income, life_satisfaction,                          weights = sampling_weight,                          show = c("mean", "sd", "skew")) #>  #> ── Weighted Descriptive Statistics ───────────────────────────────────────────── #>           Variable     Mean       SD Skewness Effective_N #>                age   50.514   17.084    0.159      2468.8 #>             income 3743.099 1423.966    0.724      2158.9 #>  life_satisfaction    3.625    1.152   -0.498      2390.9 #> ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  # Grouped analysis survey_data %>%    group_by(region) %>%    describe(age, weights = sampling_weight) #>  #> ── Weighted Descriptive Statistics ───────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #>  #> ── Group: region = East ── #>  #> ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  Variable   Mean Median     SD Range IQR Skewness Effective_N #>       age 52.278     53 17.595    77  24    0.098         477 #> ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #>  #> ── Group: region = West ── #>  #> ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  Variable   Mean Median     SD Range IQR Skewness Effective_N #>       age 50.067     49 16.927    77  24     0.17      1993.1 #> ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

what: Calculate kurtosis using the SPSS sample-corrected formula — .calc_kurtosis
title: Calculate kurtosis using the SPSS sample-corrected formula — .calc_kurtosis
text: Uses Type 2 (sample excess kurtosis) formula matching SPSS FREQUENCIES output. unweighted data: G2 = ((n+1)g2 + 6) * (n-1) / ((n-2)(n-3)) g2 = m4/m2^2 - 3 (population excess kurtosis). weighted data: Uses frequency-weighted N = sum(w) place n. Reference: Joanes & Gill (1998), "Comparing measures sample skewness kurtosis"

title: Kendall's Tau Correlation Analysis — kendall_tau
text: Calculates Kendall's tau-b rank correlation coefficients variables support weighted correlations, grouped data, multiple variable pairs. Provides significance testing SPSS-compatible output formatting. function computes tau-b, adjusted ties particularly suitable ordinal data assumptions Pearson correlation met. weighted correlations, uses survey-weighted rank calculations.

code: kendall_tau(   data,   ...,   weights = NULL,   alternative = "two.sided",   na.rm = "pairwise" )

title: Kendall's Tau Correlation Analysis — kendall_tau
text: data data frame tibble containing variables analyze ... <\code{\link[dplyr]{dplyr_tidy_select}}> Variables correlation analysis. Supports tidyselect helpers. two variables selected, correlation matrix computed. weights <\code{\link[dplyr]{dplyr_data_masking}}> Optional sampling weights weighted correlations. numeric variable positive values. alternative Character string specifying alternative hypothesis: "two.sided" (default): Two-tailed test "less": One-tailed test (negative correlation) "greater": One-tailed test (positive correlation) na.rm Character string specifying missing data handling: "pairwise" (default): Pairwise deletion - correlation uses available cases "listwise": Listwise deletion - complete cases across variables

title: Kendall's Tau Correlation Analysis — kendall_tau
text: Kendall's tau measures often pairs observations order (concordant) versus different order (discordant). particularly useful : Ordinal data (like rating scales: strongly disagree strongly agree) Data outliers (robust Pearson correlation) Small sample sizes Non-linear monotonic relationships

title: Kendall's Tau Correlation Analysis — kendall_tau
text: tau value ranges -1 +1: Strong positive (0.5 1.0): High values one variable tend go high values Moderate positive (0.3 0.5): tendency values increase together Weak positive (0 0.3): Slight tendency values increase together correlation (near 0): relationship variables Negative values: one variable increases, tends decrease

title: Kendall's Tau Correlation Analysis — kendall_tau
text: Choose Kendall's tau : data ordinal (ranked categories) small sample size (< 30 observations) data outliers might affect Pearson correlation want conservative measure Spearman's rho

title: Kendall's Tau Correlation Analysis — kendall_tau
text: function provides: tau: correlation coefficient p-value: Probability seeing correlation chance (smaller = stronger evidence) n: Number observations used significance stars: Quick visual indicator statistical significance

title: Kendall's Tau Correlation Analysis — kendall_tau
text: Kendall, M.G. (1938). new measure rank correlation. Biometrika, 30(1/2), 81-93. Kendall, M.G. (1945). treatment ties ranking problems. Biometrika, 33(3), 239-251. Agresti, . (2010). Analysis Ordinal Categorical Data (2nd ed.). John Wiley & Sons.

title: Kendall's Tau Correlation Analysis — kendall_tau
code: # Load required packages and data library(dplyr) data(survey_data)  # Basic correlation between two variables survey_data %>%   kendall_tau(life_satisfaction, political_orientation) #>  #> ── Kendall's Tau-b Correlation  ──────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> • Missing data handling: pairwise deletion #> • Alternative hypothesis: two.sided #>  #>  #> ┌─ life_satisfaction × political_orientation ─┐ #>  #>   Kendall's tau-b: τ = -0.004 #>   Sample size: n = 2228 #>   z-score: -0.212 #>   p-value (2-tailed): 0.8321 #>   Significance: ns #>  #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 #>  #> Interpretation: weak negative correlation  # Correlation matrix for multiple variables survey_data %>%   kendall_tau(life_satisfaction, political_orientation, trust_media) #>  #> ── Kendall's Tau-b Correlation  ──────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> • Missing data handling: pairwise deletion #> • Alternative hypothesis: two.sided #>  #>  #> Kendall's Tau-b Matrix: #> -----------------------  #>                       life_satisfaction political_orientation trust_media #> life_satisfaction                 1.000                -0.004       0.023 #> political_orientation            -0.004                 1.000       0.003 #> trust_media                       0.023                 0.003       1.000 #> -----------------------  #>  #> Significance Matrix (p-values, 2-tailed): #> -----------------------------------------  #>                       life_satisfaction political_orientation trust_media #> life_satisfaction                0.0000                0.8321      0.1751 #> political_orientation            0.8321                0.0000      0.8823 #> trust_media                      0.1751                0.8823      0.0000 #> -----------------------------------------  #>  #> Sample Size Matrix: #> -------------------  #>                       life_satisfaction political_orientation trust_media #> life_satisfaction                  2421                  2228        2291 #> political_orientation              2228                  2299        2177 #> trust_media                        2291                  2177        2367 #> -------------------  #>  #> Pairwise Results: #> ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>                                       Pair  tau_b      z      p    n sig #>  life_satisfaction × political_orientation -0.004 -0.212 0.8321 2228     #>            life_satisfaction × trust_media  0.023  1.356 0.1751 2291     #>        political_orientation × trust_media  0.003  0.148 0.8823 2177     #> ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05  # Weighted correlations survey_data %>%   kendall_tau(age, income, weights = sampling_weight) #>  #> ── Weighted Kendall's Tau-b Correlation  ─────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> • Weights variable: sampling_weight #> • Missing data handling: pairwise deletion #> • Alternative hypothesis: two.sided #>  #>  #> ┌─ age × income ─┐ #>  #>   Kendall's tau-b: τ = 0.003 #>   Sample size: n = 2201 #>   z-score: 0.202 #>   p-value (2-tailed): 0.8397 #>   Significance: ns #>  #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 #>  #> Interpretation: weak positive correlation  # Grouped correlations survey_data %>% what: Test If Groups Vary Similarly — levene_test
title: Test If Groups Vary Similarly — levene_test
text: levene_test() checks different groups similar amounts variation. important assumption many statistical tests - groups spread similar ways. test tells : Whether variance consistent across groups can trust standard ANOVA t-test results use alternative tests assume equal variance

title: Test If Groups Vary Similarly — levene_test
code: levene_test(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'data.frame' levene_test(x, ..., group, weights = NULL, center = c("mean", "median"))  # S3 method for class 'oneway_anova' levene_test(x, center = c("mean", "median"), ...)  # S3 method for class 't_test' levene_test(x, center = c("mean", "median"), ...)  # S3 method for class 'mann_whitney' levene_test(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'grouped_df' levene_test(x, variable, group = NULL, weights = NULL, center = "mean", ...)

title: Test If Groups Vary Similarly — levene_test
text: x Either data test results t_test() oneway_anova() ... Variables test (using data frame) group grouping variable comparison weights Optional survey weights population-representative results center measure center: "mean" (default) "median" (robust) data survey data (x test result)

title: Test If Groups Vary Similarly — levene_test
text: Test results showing: Whether groups equal variances (p-value) F-statistic measuring variance differences variables meet assumption

title: Test If Groups Vary Similarly — levene_test
text: P-value interpretation: p > 0.05: Good! Groups similar variance (assumption met) p ≤ 0.05: Problem - groups vary differently (assumption violated) Think like checking groups equally "spread ": Similar spread = can use standard tests Different spread = need special methods

title: Test If Groups Vary Similarly — levene_test
text: Check variance equality : running t-tests ANOVA Comparing groups different sizes statistical test assumes equal variances see different standard deviations

title: Test If Groups Vary Similarly — levene_test
text: Levene's test significant (p ≤ 0.05): t-tests: Use Welch's t-test (var.equal = FALSE) ANOVA: Use Welch's ANOVA Consider transforming data Use non-parametric alternatives Report equal variance assumption violated

title: Test If Groups Vary Similarly — levene_test
text: can use function two ways: Standalone: Check variables equal variance tests: Pipe t_test() oneway_anova() verify assumptions

title: Test If Groups Vary Similarly — levene_test
text: Always check assumption group comparisons Visual inspection (boxplots) can supplement test Large samples make test sensitive Use median-based test skewed data (center = "median") panic violated - alternatives exist!

title: Test If Groups Vary Similarly — levene_test
code: # Load required packages and data library(dplyr) data(survey_data)  # Standalone Levene test (test homogeneity of variances) survey_data %>% levene_test(life_satisfaction, group = region) #>  #> ── Levene's Test for Homogeneity of Variance  ────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Grouping variable: region #> Center: mean #>  #>  #> --- life_satisfaction --- #>  #> Levene's Test Results: #> ------------------------------------------------------------------  #>           Variable F_statistic df1  df2 p_value sig      Conclusion #>  life_satisfaction       3.164   1 2419   0.075     Variances equal #> ------------------------------------------------------------------  #>  #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 #>  #> Interpretation: #> - p > 0.05: Variances are homogeneous (equal variances assumed) #> - p <= 0.05: Variances are heterogeneous (equal variances NOT assumed)  # Multiple variables survey_data %>% levene_test(life_satisfaction, trust_government, group = region) #>  #> ── Levene's Test for Homogeneity of Variance  ────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Grouping variable: region #> Center: mean #>  #>  #> --- life_satisfaction --- #>  #> Levene's Test Results: #> ------------------------------------------------------------------  #>           Variable F_statistic df1  df2 p_value sig      Conclusion #>  life_satisfaction       3.164   1 2419   0.075     Variances equal #> ------------------------------------------------------------------  #>  #>  #> --- trust_government --- #>  #> Levene's Test Results: #> -----------------------------------------------------------------  #>          Variable F_statistic df1  df2 p_value sig      Conclusion #>  trust_government       0.145   1 2352   0.703     Variances equal #> -----------------------------------------------------------------  #>  #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 #>  #> Interpretation: #> - p > 0.05: Variances are homogeneous (equal variances assumed) #> - p <= 0.05: Variances are heterogeneous (equal variances NOT assumed)  # Weighted analysis survey_data %>% levene_test(income, group = education, weights = sampling_weight) #>  #> ── Weighted Levene's Test for Homogeneity of Variance  ───────────────────────── #>  #> Grouping variable: education #> Weights variable: sampling_weight #> Center: mean #>  #>  #> --- income --- #>  #> Weighted Levene's Test Results: #> -----------------------------------------------------------  #>  Variable F_statistic df1  df2 p_value sig        Conclusion #>    income      102.05   3 2197       0 *** Variances unequal #> -----------------------------------------------------------  #>  #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 #>  #> Interpretation: #> - p > 0.05: Variances are homogeneous (equal variances assumed) #> - p <= 0.05: Variances are heterogeneous (equal variances NOT assumed)  # Piped after ANOVA (common workflow) result <- survey_data %>%   oneway_anova(life_satisfaction, group = education) result %>% levene_test() #>  #> ── Levene's Test for Homogeneity of Variance  ────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Grouping variable: education #> Center: mean #>  #>  #> --- life_satisfaction --- #>  #> Levene's Test Results: #> --------------------------------------------------------------------  #>           Variable F_statistic df1  df2 p_value sig        Conclusion #>  life_satisfaction      31.634   3 2417       0 *** Variances unequal #> --------------------------------------------------------------------  #>  #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 #>  #> Interpretation: #> - p > 0.05: Variances are homogeneous (equal variances assumed) #> - p <= 0.05: Variances are heterogeneous (equal variances NOT assumed) #>  #> Recommendation based on Levene test: #> - Use Welch's t-test (unequal variances)  # Piped after t-test survey_data %>%   t_test(age, group = gender) %>%   levene_test() #>  #> ── Levene's Test for Homogeneity of Variance  ────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Grouping variable: gender #> Center: mean #>  #>  #> --- age --- #>  #> Levene's Test Results: #> ---------------------------------------------------------  #>  Variable F_statistic df1  df2 p_value sig      Conclusion #>       age       0.534   1 2498   0.465     Variances equal #> ---------------------------------------------------------  #>  #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 #>  #> Interpretation: #> - p > 0.05: Variances are homogeneous (equal variances assumed) #> - p <= 0.05: Variances are heterogeneous (equal variances NOT assumed) #>  #> Recommendation based on Levene test: #> - Student's t-test or Welch's t-test both appropriate  # Using mean instead of median as center survey_data %>% levene_test(income, group = region, center = "mean") #>  #> ── Levene's Test for Homogeneity of Variance  ────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Grouping variable: region #> Center: mean #>  #>  #> --- income --- #>  #> Levene's Test Results: #> ---------------------------------------------------------  #>  Variable F_statistic df1  df2 p_value sig      Conclusion #>    income       1.631   1 2184   0.202     Variances equal #> ---------------------------------------------------------  #>  #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 #>  #> Interpretation: #> - p > 0.05: Variances are homogeneous (equal variances assumed) #> - p <= 0.05: Variances are heterogeneous (equal variances NOT assumed)

title: Longitudinal Study Data (Synthetic) — longitudinal_data
text: Generated synthetically realistic longitudinal correlation patterns treatment effects. real study data used.

title: Longitudinal Study Data (Synthetic) — longitudinal_data
text: Study design features: 120 subjects (60 per group) 4 measurement occasions Balanced treatment assignment Realistic dropout patterns (0% T1, 35% T4) Treatment effect grows time (interaction effect) Autoregressive error structure Effect size approximately Cohen's d = 0.6 Missing data patterns reflect realistic longitudinal study attrition higher dropout later time points. treatment effect demonstrates clear Group x Time interaction suitable repeated measures testing.

what: Compare Two Groups Without Assuming Normal Data — mann_whitney
title: Compare Two Groups Without Assuming Normal Data — mann_whitney
text: mann_whitney() compares two groups data normally distributed ordinal data (like ratings rankings). go-alternative t-tests appropriate. Think : robust way compare groups works data shape Perfect Likert scales, ratings, skewed distributions test compares typical values groups test tells : Whether one group tends higher values strong difference (effect size) group higher average ranks

title: Compare Two Groups Without Assuming Normal Data — mann_whitney
code: mann_whitney(   data,   ...,   group,   weights = NULL,   mu = 0,   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),   conf.level = 0.95 )

title: Compare Two Groups Without Assuming Normal Data — mann_whitney
text: data survey data (data frame tibble) ... variables want compare groups. can list multiple variables use helpers like starts_with("satisfaction") group categorical variable defines two groups (e.g., gender, treatment/control). Must exactly two groups. weights Optional survey weights population-representative results mu hypothesized difference (Default: 0, meaning difference) alternative Direction test: "two.sided" (default): Test groups different "greater": Test group 1 > group 2 "less": Test group 1 < group 2 conf.level Confidence level effect size (Default: 0.95 = 95%)

title: Compare Two Groups Without Assuming Normal Data — mann_whitney
text: Test results showing whether groups differ, including: U W statistics (test statistics) Z-score p-value (groups different?) Effect size r (big difference?) Rank means group (group higher?)

title: Compare Two Groups Without Assuming Normal Data — mann_whitney
text: P-value: p < 0.05, groups significantly different p < 0.001: strong evidence difference p < 0.01: Strong evidence difference p < 0.05: Moderate evidence difference p ≥ 0.05: significant difference found Effect Size r (big difference?): |r| < 0.1: Negligible difference |r| ~ 0.1: Small difference |r| ~ 0.3: Medium difference |r| ~ 0.5: Large difference |r| > 0.5: large difference Rank Mean Difference: Positive: Group 1 tends higher values Negative: Group 2 tends higher values Zero: Groups similar distributions

title: Compare Two Groups Without Assuming Normal Data — mann_whitney
text: Use Mann-Whitney test : data normally distributed (skewed, outliers) ordinal data (rankings, Likert scales) Sample sizes small (< 30 per group) want robust alternative t-test comparing satisfaction ratings, income, skewed variables

title: Compare Two Groups Without Assuming Normal Data — mann_whitney
text: Works data distribution affected outliers Valid ordinal data assumptions variance robust real-world data

title: Compare Two Groups Without Assuming Normal Data — mann_whitney
text: group least 5 observations test compares distributions, just means Look p-values effect sizes Consider plotting data see pattern Use Likert scales rating data

title: Compare Two Groups Without Assuming Normal Data — mann_whitney
text: Mann, H. B., & Whitney, D. R. (1947). test whether one two random variables stochastically larger . Annals Mathematical Statistics, 18(1), 50-60. Wilcoxon, F. (1945). Individual comparisons ranking methods. Biometrics Bulletin, 1(6), 80-83.

what: Compare Multiple Groups: Are Their Averages Different? — oneway_anova
title: Compare Multiple Groups: Are Their Averages Different? — oneway_anova
text: oneway_anova() helps determine average values differ across three groups. example, average income vary education level? customer satisfaction different across regions? Think : extension t-test two groups way test group membership affects outcomes tool identify meaningful group differences test tells : Whether least one group different others much variation explained group membership variance assumption fits data best

title: Compare Multiple Groups: Are Their Averages Different? — oneway_anova
code: oneway_anova(   data,   ...,   group,   weights = NULL,   var.equal = TRUE,   conf.level = 0.95 )

title: Compare Multiple Groups: Are Their Averages Different? — oneway_anova
text: data survey data (data frame tibble) ... numeric variables want analyze. can list multiple variables use helpers like starts_with("income") group categorical variable defines groups (e.g., education, region, age_group). Must least 3 groups ANOVA. weights Optional survey weights population-representative results var.equal assume groups similar variance? (Default: TRUE) TRUE: Standard ANOVA (assumes equal variances) FALSE: Welch's ANOVA (allows unequal variances) conf.level Confidence level group statistics (Default: 0.95 = 95%)

title: Compare Multiple Groups: Are Their Averages Different? — oneway_anova
text: ANOVA results showing whether groups differ, including: F-statistic p-value (groups different?) Effect sizes (much groups matter?) Group statistics (means standard deviations) standard Welch ANOVA results

title: Compare Multiple Groups: Are Their Averages Different? — oneway_anova
text: P-value: p < 0.05, least one group average different p < 0.001: strong evidence group differences p < 0.01: Strong evidence group differences p < 0.05: Moderate evidence group differences p ≥ 0.05: significant group differences found Effect Sizes (much groups matter?): Eta-squared: Proportion variance explained groups < 0.01: Negligible effect 0.01-0.06: Small effect 0.06-0.14: Medium effect 0.14 higher: Large effect Omega-squared: conservative estimate (usually preferred)

title: Compare Multiple Groups: Are Their Averages Different? — oneway_anova
text: Use ANOVA : one numeric outcome (income, satisfaction score, etc.) one categorical grouping variable 3+ groups want know group averages differ data roughly normally distributed within groups

title: Compare Multiple Groups: Are Their Averages Different? — oneway_anova
text: Standard ANOVA (var.equal = TRUE): Use group variances similar Welch's ANOVA (var.equal = FALSE): Use group variances differ unsure function shows results comparison

title: Compare Multiple Groups: Are Their Averages Different? — oneway_anova
text: ANOVA significant: Look group means see pattern Use tukey_test() find specific groups differ Consider effect sizes judge practical importance

title: Compare Multiple Groups: Are Their Averages Different? — oneway_anova
text: Check group sufficient observations (ideally 20+) Look p-values effect sizes Use Welch's ANOVA group sizes unequal Follow post-hoc tests identify specific differences Welch's robust test equality means

title: Compare Multiple Groups: Are Their Averages Different? — oneway_anova
text: p-values: p < 0.05 indicates significant group differences alpha = 0.05 Effect sizes: eta-squared ~ 0.01 (small), eta-squared ~ 0.06 (medium), eta-squared ~ 0.14 (large) Eta-squared: Proportion variance explained (tends overestimate) Epsilon-squared: Less biased eta-squared Omega-squared: Unbiased estimate (preferred publication)

title: Compare Multiple Groups: Are Their Averages Different? — oneway_anova
text: Cohen, J. (1988). Statistical Power Analysis Behavioral Sciences (2nd ed.). Lawrence Erlbaum Associates. Welch, B. L. (1951). comparison several mean values: alternative approach. Biometrika, 38(3/4), 330-336. Olejnik, S., & Algina, J. (2003). Generalized eta omega squared statistics: measures effect size common research designs. Psychological Methods, 8(4), 434-447.

Grouping variable: education #> Center: mean #>  #>  #> --- life_satisfaction --- #>  #> Levene's Test Results: #> --------------------------------------------------------------------  #> what: Measure How Strongly Variables Are Related — pearson_cor
title: Measure How Strongly Variables Are Related — pearson_cor
text: pearson_cor() shows strongly numeric variables related . example, age related income? satisfaction increase experience? helps understand patterns data. correlation tells : Direction: Positive (increase together) negative (one increases decreases) Strength: closely variables move together (0 = relationship 1 = perfect relationship) Significance: Whether relationship real due chance

title: Measure How Strongly Variables Are Related — pearson_cor
code: pearson_cor(data, ..., weights = NULL, conf.level = 0.95, na.rm = "pairwise")

title: Measure How Strongly Variables Are Related — pearson_cor
text: data survey data (data frame tibble) ... numeric variables want correlate. List two single correlation correlation matrix. weights Optional survey weights population-representative results conf.level Confidence level intervals (Default: 0.95 = 95%) na.rm handle missing values: "pairwise" (default): Use available data pair "listwise": use complete cases across variables

title: Measure How Strongly Variables Are Related — pearson_cor
text: Correlation results showing relationships variables, including: Correlation coefficient (r): Strength direction relationship P-value: Whether relationship statistically significant Confidence interval: Range plausible correlation values Sample size: Number observations used

title: Measure How Strongly Variables Are Related — pearson_cor
text: Correlation coefficient (r) ranges -1 +1: +1: Perfect positive relationship (one goes , always goes ) 0: linear relationship -1: Perfect negative relationship (one goes , always goes ) Interpreting strength (absolute value r): 0.00 - 0.10: Negligible relationship 0.10 - 0.30: Weak relationship 0.30 - 0.50: Moderate relationship 0.50 - 0.70: Strong relationship 0.70 - 0.90: strong relationship 0.90 - 1.00: Extremely strong relationship P-value interpretation: p < 0.001: strong evidence relationship p < 0.01: Strong evidence relationship p < 0.05: Moderate evidence relationship p ≥ 0.05: significant relationship found

title: Measure How Strongly Variables Are Related — pearson_cor
text: Use : variables numeric continuous expect linear relationship Data roughly normally distributed want measure strength linear association use : Data extreme outliers (consider Spearman instead) Relationship curved/non-linear Variables categorical (use chi-squared test) need establish causation (correlation ≠ causation!)

title: Measure How Strongly Variables Are Related — pearson_cor
text: correlation 0.65 p < 0.001 means: Strong positive relationship (r = 0.65) one variable increases, tends increase unlikely due chance (p < 0.001) 42% variation shared (r² = 0.65² = 0.42)

title: Measure How Strongly Variables Are Related — pearson_cor
text: Always plot data first check non-linear patterns Consider statistical significance (p-value) practical importance (r value) Remember: correlation imply causation Check outliers might inflate deflate correlations Use Spearman correlation ordinal data non-normal distributions

title: Measure How Strongly Variables Are Related — pearson_cor
text: Cohen, J. (1988). Statistical Power Analysis Behavioral Sciences (2nd ed.). Lawrence Erlbaum Associates. Fisher, R.. (1915). Frequency distribution values correlation coefficient samples indefinitely large population. Biometrika, 10(4), 507-521.

title: Compare All Groups More Conservatively After ANOVA — scheffe_test
text: Adjusted P-values: Extra conservative prevent false positives p < 0.05: Groups significantly different (can confident) p ≥ 0.05: significant difference groups Scheffe adjustments stricter methods Confidence Intervals: Wider Tukey's include 0: Groups differ significantly Include 0: significant difference Wider intervals reflect extra caution

title: Compare All Groups More Conservatively After ANOVA — scheffe_test
text: Use Scheffe test : ANOVA shows significant differences (p < 0.05) Group sizes unequal want extra cautious false positives might test complex comparisons (just pairs) Sample sizes small

title: Compare All Groups More Conservatively After ANOVA — scheffe_test
text: Scheffe Test: conservative (hardest find differences) Best unequal group sizes Protects possible comparisons Wider confidence intervals Tukey Test: Less conservative (easier find differences) Best equal group sizes Protects pairwise comparisons Narrower confidence intervals

title: Compare All Groups More Conservatively After ANOVA — scheffe_test
text: Example: "Group - Group B: Diff = 3.2, p = 0.082" Group 's average 3.2 units higher Group B's difference significant Scheffe (p > 0.05) might significant less conservative tests

title: Compare All Groups More Conservatively After ANOVA — scheffe_test
text: Scheffe may find differences even ANOVA normal - extra careful Consider Tukey group sizes similar Report post-hoc test used Focus confidence intervals, just p-values

title: Compare All Groups More Conservatively After ANOVA — scheffe_test
code: # Load required packages and data library(dplyr) data(survey_data)  # Perform ANOVA followed by Scheffe post-hoc test anova_result <- survey_data %>%   oneway_anova(life_satisfaction, group = education)  # Scheffe post-hoc comparisons anova_result %>% scheffe_test() #> ── Scheffe Post-Hoc Test Results ─────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Dependent Variable: life_satisfaction #> Grouping Variable: education #> Confidence level: 95.0% #> Family-wise error rate controlled using Scheffe's method #> Note: Most conservative post-hoc test (widest confidence intervals) #>  #>  #> --- life_satisfaction --- #>  #> Scheffe Results: #> ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  #>                                   Comparison Difference Lower CI Upper CI #>     Basic Secondary - Intermediate Secondary     -0.497   -0.662   -0.331 #>         Basic Secondary - Academic Secondary     -0.649   -0.816   -0.483 #>                 Basic Secondary - University     -0.843   -1.034   -0.651 #>  Intermediate Secondary - Academic Secondary     -0.153   -0.330    0.024 #>          Intermediate Secondary - University     -0.346   -0.547   -0.145 #>              Academic Secondary - University     -0.193   -0.395    0.009 #>  p-value Sig #>    <.001 *** #>    <.001 *** #>    <.001 *** #>    0.121     #>    <.001 *** #>    0.067     #> ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  #>  #>  #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 #>  #> Interpretation: #> - Positive differences: First group > Second group #> - Negative differences: First group < Second group #> - Confidence intervals not containing 0 indicate significant differences #> - p-values are adjusted for all possible contrasts (most conservative) #> - Scheffe test has wider CIs than Tukey HSD  # Multiple variables anova_result_multi <- survey_data %>%   oneway_anova(life_satisfaction, income, group = education)  anova_result_multi %>% scheffe_test() #> ── Scheffe Post-Hoc Test Results ─────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Grouping Variable: education #> Confidence level: 95.0% #> Family-wise error rate controlled using Scheffe's method #> Note: Most conservative post-hoc test (widest confidence intervals) #>  #>  #> --- life_satisfaction --- #>  #> Scheffe Results: #> ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  #>                                   Comparison Difference Lower CI Upper CI #>     Basic Secondary - Intermediate Secondary   -833.471 -1010.178  -656.763 #>         Basic Secondary - Academic Secondary  -1465.040 -1641.748 -1288.332 #>                 Basic Secondary - University  -2578.135 -2780.499 -2375.772 #>  Intermediate Secondary - Academic Secondary   -631.569  -820.717  -442.422 #>          Intermediate Secondary - University  -1744.665 -1957.977 -1531.353 #>              Academic Secondary - University  -1113.096 -1326.408  -899.783 #>  p-value Sig #>    <.001 *** #>    <.001 *** #>    <.001 *** #>    <.001 *** #>    <.001 *** #>    <.001 *** #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  #>  #>  #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 #>  #> Interpretation: #> - Scheffe test has wider CIs than Tukey HSD  # Weighted analysis anova_weighted <- survey_data %>%   oneway_anova(life_satisfaction, group = education, weights = sampling_weight)  anova_weighted %>% scheffe_test() #> ── Weighted Scheffe Post-Hoc Test Results ────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Dependent Variable: life_satisfaction #> Grouping Variable: education #> Weights Variable: sampling_weight #> Confidence level: 95.0% #> Family-wise error rate controlled using Scheffe's method #> Note: Most conservative post-hoc test (widest confidence intervals) #>  #>  #> --- life_satisfaction --- #>  #> Weighted Scheffe Results: #> ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  #>                                   Comparison Difference Lower CI Upper CI #>     Basic Secondary - Academic Secondary     -0.153   -0.329    0.023 #>          Intermediate Secondary - University     -0.342   -0.545   -0.140 #>              Academic Secondary - University     -0.189   -0.393    0.014 #>  p-value Sig #>    <.001 *** #>    <.001 *** #>    <.001 *** #>    0.115     #>    <.001 *** #>    0.079     #> ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  #>  #>  #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 #>  #> Interpretation: #> - Academic Secondary     -0.142   -0.335    0.052 #>          Intermediate Secondary - University     -0.355   -0.575   -0.135 #>              Academic Secondary - University     -0.213   -0.434    0.007 #>  p-value Sig #>    <.001 *** #>    <.001 *** #>    <.001 *** #>     0.24     #>    <.001 *** #>    0.062     #> ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  #>  #>  #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 #>  #> Interpretation: #> - title: Spearman's Rank Correlation Analysis — spearman_rho
text: Calculates Spearman's rank correlation coefficients (rho) variables support weighted correlations, grouped data, multiple variable pairs. Provides significance testing SPSS-compatible output formatting. Spearman's rho non-parametric measure rank correlation assesses monotonic relationships variables. particularly suitable ordinal data assumptions Pearson correlation met.

title: Spearman's Rank Correlation Analysis — spearman_rho
code: spearman_rho(   data,   ...,   weights = NULL,   alternative = "two.sided",   na.rm = "pairwise" )

title: Spearman's Rank Correlation Analysis — spearman_rho
text: data data frame tibble containing variables analyze ... <\code{\link[dplyr]{dplyr_tidy_select}}> Variables correlation analysis. Supports tidyselect helpers. two variables selected, correlation matrix computed. weights <\code{\link[dplyr]{dplyr_data_masking}}> Optional sampling weights weighted correlations. numeric variable positive values. Note: SPSS may apply weights Spearman's rho; implementation uses weighted ranks mathematically correct survey analysis. alternative Character string specifying alternative hypothesis: "two.sided" (default): Two-tailed test "less": One-tailed test (negative correlation) "greater": One-tailed test (positive correlation) na.rm Character string specifying missing data handling: "pairwise" (default): Pairwise deletion - correlation uses available cases "listwise": Listwise deletion - complete cases across variables

title: Spearman's Rank Correlation Analysis — spearman_rho
text: Spearman's rho measures strength direction monotonic relationship two variables. Unlike Pearson correlation, require linear relationship - just needs one variable consistently increase (decrease) increases. Think ranking data first, checking ranks tend go together.

title: Spearman's Rank Correlation Analysis — spearman_rho
text: rho value ranges -1 +1: Strong positive (0.7 1.0): High ranks one variable go high ranks Moderate positive (0.3 0.7): Moderate tendency ranks increase together Weak positive (0 0.3): Slight tendency ranks increase together correlation (near 0): relationship variables Negative values: one variable's rank increases, 's tends decrease

title: Spearman's Rank Correlation Analysis — spearman_rho
text: Choose Spearman's rho : relationship monotonic necessarily linear data outliers (less impact ranks) variables ordinal (ordered categories) sure data meets Pearson correlation assumptions want detect monotonic trend, just linear ones

title: Spearman's Rank Correlation Analysis — spearman_rho
text: Spearman's rho usually larger magnitude Kendall's tau Spearman's rho better detecting linear relationships ranks Kendall's tau robust better statistical properties Spearman's rho commonly reported research

title: Spearman's Rank Correlation Analysis — spearman_rho
text: function provides: rho: rank correlation coefficient p-value: Probability seeing correlation chance n: Number observation pairs used significance stars: Visual indicator (*** strong, ** strong, * moderate evidence)

title: Spearman's Rank Correlation Analysis — spearman_rho
text: Spearman, C. (1904). proof measurement association two things. American Journal Psychology, 15(1), 72-101. Lehmann, E.L. (1975). Nonparametrics: Statistical Methods Based Ranks. Holden-Day.

title: Social Survey Data (Synthetic) — survey_data
text: data frame 2,500 rows 16 variables: id Unique identifier (1-2500) age Age years (18-95) gender Gender (Male, Female) region Region (East, West) education Education level (Basic Secondary, Intermediate Secondary, Academic Secondary, University) income Monthly household income EUR (800-15000) employment Employment status (Student, Employed, Unemployed, Retired, ) political_orientation Political orientation (1=left 5=right) environmental_concern Environmental concern (1=concerned 5=concerned) life_satisfaction Life satisfaction (1=dissatisfied 5=satisfied) trust_government Trust government (1=trust 5=complete trust) trust_media Trust media (1=trust 5=complete trust) trust_science Trust science (1=trust 5=complete trust) sampling_weight Post-stratification sampling weight (0.7-1.4) stratum Stratification variable combining region age group interview_mode Interview mode (Face--face, Telephone, Online)

title: Social Survey Data (Synthetic) — survey_data
text: Generated synthetically using realistic demographic attitudinal patterns. real survey data used.

title: Social Survey Data (Synthetic) — survey_data
text: dataset contains realistic patterns correlation variables: Education correlates income political attitudes Regional differences reflect East/West patterns Age effects employment attitudes Realistic missing data patterns (3-12% depending sensitivity) Survey weights post-stratification adjustment data includes proper variable labels follows social survey conventions coding structure. Generated set.seed(2024) reproducibility.

what: Test If Two Groups Differ — t_test
title: Test If Two Groups Differ — t_test
text: t_test() helps determine two groups different average values. example, men women different satisfaction scores? Region spend Region B? year better last year? test tells : Whether difference statistically significant big difference (effect sizes) likely range true difference (confidence interval)

title: Test If Two Groups Differ — t_test
code: t_test(   data,   ...,   group = NULL,   weights = NULL,   var.equal = FALSE,   mu = 0,   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),   conf.level = 0.95 )

title: Test If Two Groups Differ — t_test
text: data survey data (data frame tibble) ... numeric variables test. List multiple variables use tidyselect helpers like starts_with("trust"). group variable defines two groups (e.g., gender, region). Must exactly two categories. Leave empty one-sample tests. weights Optional survey weights population-representative results var.equal assume equal variances? (Default: FALSE) FALSE: Safer, works even groups vary differently (Welch's test) TRUE: Traditional approach, assumes equal spread (Student's test) mu Comparison value (Default: 0). two-sample tests, usually 0. one-sample tests, benchmark value. alternative Direction test: "two.sided" (default): difference "greater": First group higher "less": First group lower conf.level Confidence level (Default: 0.95 = 95%)

title: Test If Two Groups Differ — t_test
text: Test results showing whether groups differ, including: t-statistic p-value statistical significance Mean difference confidence interval Effect sizes (Cohen's d, Hedges' g, Glass' Delta) Group statistics (mean, SD, sample size)

title: Test If Two Groups Differ — t_test
text: P-value: difference statistically significant? p < 0.001: strong evidence difference p < 0.01: Strong evidence difference p < 0.05: Moderate evidence difference p ≥ 0.05: significant difference found Effect Sizes (big difference?): Cohen's d: standard measure |d| < 0.2: Negligible difference |d| = 0.2-0.5: Small difference |d| = 0.5-0.8: Medium difference |d| > 0.8: Large difference Hedges' g: Corrected small samples Glass' Delta: Uses control group SD Confidence Interval: Range true difference likely falls includes 0, groups may differ Width indicates precision (narrower = precise)

title: Test If Two Groups Differ — t_test
text: Use t-test : exactly two groups compare outcome variable numeric (continuous) Groups independent (different people ) Data roughly normally distributed (n ≥ 30 per group) use : two groups (use ANOVA) Data severely skewed small samples (use Mann-Whitney) Groups paired/matched (use paired t-test - coming soon) Variables categorical (use chi-square)

title: Test If Two Groups Differ — t_test
text: results show variance assumptions: Welch's test (var.equal = FALSE): Safer, assume equal variances Student's test (var.equal = TRUE): Traditional, assumes equal variances result t = 2.45, p = 0.015, d = 0.62 means: Groups 2.45 standard errors apart (t-statistic) 1.5% chance due random variation (p-value) Medium-sized practical difference (Cohen's d)

title: Test If Two Groups Differ — t_test
text: Always check sample sizes (aim 30+ per group) Consider statistical significance effect size Use weights population-level conclusions Plot data first check assumptions Report confidence intervals along p-values

title: Test If Two Groups Differ — t_test
text: Cohen, J. (1988). Statistical Power Analysis Behavioral Sciences (2nd ed.). Lawrence Erlbaum Associates. Hedges, L. V. (1981). Distribution theory Glass's estimator effect size related estimators. Journal Educational Statistics, 6(2), 107-128. Glass, G. V. (1976). Primary, secondary, meta-analysis research. Educational Researcher, 5(10), 3-8. Welch, B. L. (1947). generalization "Student's" problem several different population variances involved. Biometrika, 34(1-2), 28-35.

what: Find Which Specific Groups Differ After ANOVA — tukey_test
title: Find Which Specific Groups Differ After ANOVA — tukey_test
text: tukey_test() tells exactly groups different ANOVA finds overall differences. like follow-investigation pinpoints differences lie. Think : ANOVA says "differences somewhere" Tukey test says "specifically, Group differs Group C" way make possible comparisons controlling error rates

title: Find Which Specific Groups Differ After ANOVA — tukey_test
code: tukey_test(x, conf.level = 0.95, ...)

title: Find Which Specific Groups Differ After ANOVA — tukey_test
text: x ANOVA results oneway_anova() conf.level Confidence level intervals (Default: 0.95 = 95%) ... Additional arguments (currently unused)

title: Find Which Specific Groups Differ After ANOVA — tukey_test
text: Pairwise comparison results showing: group pairs significantly different Size difference pair Adjusted p-values (controlling multiple comparisons) Confidence intervals difference

title: Find Which Specific Groups Differ After ANOVA — tukey_test
text: Adjusted P-values: Control multiple comparisons p < 0.05: Groups significantly different p ≥ 0.05: significant difference groups make many comparisons, chance alone produce false positives Tukey adjustment protects conservative Mean Differences: Positive: First group higher average second Negative: Second group higher average first Zero confidence interval: significant difference

title: Find Which Specific Groups Differ After ANOVA — tukey_test
text: Use Tukey test : ANOVA shows significant differences (p < 0.05) want know specific groups differ need compare possible pairs Group sizes roughly equal Variances roughly equal across groups

title: Find Which Specific Groups Differ After ANOVA — tukey_test
text: Tukey Test: Less conservative (easier find differences) Best equal group sizes Protects pairwise comparisons Narrower confidence intervals Scheffe Test: conservative (hardest find differences) Best unequal group sizes Protects possible comparisons Wider confidence intervals

title: Find Which Specific Groups Differ After ANOVA — tukey_test
text: Example: "Group - Group B: Diff = 3.2, p = 0.012" Group 's average 3.2 units higher Group B's difference statistically significant (p < 0.05) can confident groups truly differ

title: Find Which Specific Groups Differ After ANOVA — tukey_test
text: run post-hoc tests ANOVA significant Focus comparisons make theoretical sense Consider practical significance, just statistical Report difference confidence interval Remember: non-significant mean "exactly equal"

title: Find Which Specific Groups Differ After ANOVA — tukey_test
text: Tukey, J. W. (1949). Comparing individual means analysis variance. Biometrics, 5(2), 99-114. Kramer, C. Y. (1956). Extension multiple range tests group means unequal numbers replications. Biometrics, 12(3), 307-310.

title: Find Which Specific Groups Differ After ANOVA — tukey_test
code: # Load required packages and data library(dplyr) data(survey_data)  # Perform ANOVA followed by Tukey post-hoc test anova_result <- survey_data %>%   oneway_anova(life_satisfaction, group = education)  # Tukey post-hoc comparisons anova_result %>% tukey_test() #> ── Tukey HSD Post-Hoc Test Results ───────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Dependent Variable: life_satisfaction #> Grouping Variable: education #> Confidence level: 95.0% #> Family-wise error rate controlled using Tukey HSD #>  #>  #> --- life_satisfaction --- #>  #> Tukey Results: #> ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------  #>                                 Comparison Difference Lower CI Upper CI p-value #>     Intermediate Secondary-Basic Secondary      0.497    0.344    0.649   <.001 #>         Academic Secondary-Basic Secondary      0.649    0.496    0.802   <.001 #>                 University-Basic Secondary      0.843    0.666    1.019   <.001 #>  Academic Secondary-Intermediate Secondary      0.153   -0.010    0.316   0.075 #>          University-Intermediate Secondary      0.346    0.161    0.531   <.001 #>              University-Academic Secondary      0.193    0.008    0.379   0.037 #>  Sig #>  *** #>  *** #>  *** #>      #>  *** #>    * #> ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------  #>  #>  #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 #>  #> Interpretation: #> - Positive differences: First group > Second group #> - Negative differences: First group < Second group #> - Confidence intervals not containing 0 indicate significant differences #> - p-values are adjusted for multiple comparisons (family-wise error control)  # With weights anova_weighted <- survey_data %>%   oneway_anova(life_satisfaction, group = education, weights = sampling_weight)  anova_weighted %>% tukey_test() #> ── Weighted Tukey HSD Post-Hoc Test Results ──────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Dependent Variable: life_satisfaction #> Grouping Variable: education #> Weights Variable: sampling_weight #> Confidence level: 95.0% #> Family-wise error rate controlled using Tukey HSD #>  #>  #> --- life_satisfaction --- #>  #> Weighted Tukey Results: #> ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  #>                                   Comparison Difference Lower CI Upper CI #>     Basic Secondary - Intermediate Secondary     -0.490   -0.641   -0.339 #>         Basic Secondary - Academic Secondary     -0.643   -0.795   -0.491 #>                 Basic Secondary - University     -0.832   -1.011   -0.654 #>  Intermediate Secondary - Academic Secondary     -0.153   -0.314    0.008 #>          Intermediate Secondary - University     -0.342   -0.529   -0.156 #>              Academic Secondary - University     -0.189   -0.376   -0.003 #>  p-value Sig #>    <.001 *** #>    <.001 *** #>    <.001 *** #>    0.071     #>    <.001 *** #>    0.046   * #> ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  #>  #>  #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 #>  #> Interpretation: #> - Positive differences: First group > Second group #> - Negative differences: First group < Second group #> - Confidence intervals not containing 0 indicate significant differences #> - p-values are adjusted for multiple comparisons (family-wise error control)  # Multiple variables anova_multi <- survey_data %>%   oneway_anova(trust_government, trust_companies, group = education) #> Error in oneway_anova(., trust_government, trust_companies, group = education): Can't select columns that don't exist. #> ✖ Column `trust_companies` doesn't exist.  anova_multi %>% tukey_test() #> Error: object 'anova_multi' not found  # Grouped analysis anova_grouped <- survey_data %>%   group_by(region) %>%   oneway_anova(life_satisfaction, group = education)  anova_grouped %>% tukey_test() #> ── Tukey HSD Post-Hoc Test Results ───────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Grouping Variable: education #> Confidence level: 95.0% #> Family-wise error rate controlled using Tukey HSD #>  #>  #> Group: region = title: Weighted Interquartile Range (IQR) — w_iqr
text: data data frame, numeric vector used summarise() context ... Variable names (unquoted) tidyselect expressions weights Name weights variable (unquoted), numeric vector weights na.rm Logical; TRUE, missing values removed (default: TRUE)

title: Weighted Interquartile Range (IQR) — w_iqr

title: Weighted Interquartile Range (IQR) — w_iqr
code: # Load required packages and data library(dplyr) data(survey_data)  # Basic weighted IQR survey_data %>% w_iqr(age, weights = sampling_weight) #>  #> ── Weighted Interquartile Range Statistics ───────────────────────────────────── #>  #> --- age --- #>  Variable weighted_iqr Effective_N #>       age           25      2468.8 #>   # Multiple variables survey_data %>% w_iqr(age, income, weights = sampling_weight) #>  #> ── Weighted Interquartile Range Statistics ───────────────────────────────────── #>  #> --- age --- #>  Variable weighted_iqr Effective_N #>       age           25      2468.8 #>  #> --- income --- #>  Variable weighted_iqr Effective_N #>    income         1900      2158.9 #>   # Grouped data survey_data %>% group_by(region) %>% w_iqr(age, weights = sampling_weight) #>  #> ── Weighted Interquartile Range Statistics ───────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Group: region = East #> Warning: Unknown or uninitialised column: `Variable`. #>  #> Group: region = West #> Warning: Unknown or uninitialised column: `Variable`. #>   # In summarise context survey_data %>% summarise(iqr_age = w_iqr(age, weights = sampling_weight)) #> # A tibble: 1 × 1 #>   iqr_age #>     <dbl> #> 1      25  # Unweighted (for comparison) survey_data %>% w_iqr(age) #>  #> ── Interquartile Range Statistics ────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> --- age --- #>  Variable iqr    N #>       age  24 2500 #>

title: Calculate Population-Representative Averages — w_mean
text: w_mean() calculates averages accurately represent population using survey weights. ensures groups - -sampled contribute appropriately final average.

title: Calculate Population-Representative Averages — w_mean
code: w_mean(data, ..., weights = NULL, na.rm = TRUE)

title: Calculate Population-Representative Averages — w_mean
text: data survey data (data frame tibble) ... numeric variables want average. can list multiple variables use helpers like starts_with("income") weights Survey weights make average representative population. Without weights, get simple sample average. na.rm Remove missing values calculating? (Default: TRUE)

title: Calculate Population-Representative Averages — w_mean
text: Population-weighted average(s) sample size information

title: Calculate Population-Representative Averages — w_mean
text: Survey samples rarely match population perfectly. Weights correct : Oversampling certain groups (weights < 1) Undersampling groups (weights > 1) Non-response patterns Complex survey designs

title: Calculate Population-Representative Averages — w_mean
text: Weighted Mean: population-representative average Effective N: many independent observations weighted data represents N: Actual number observations used

title: Calculate Population-Representative Averages — w_mean
text: Weighted mean: \(\bar{x}_w = \sum(w_i \cdot x_i) / \sum(w_i)\)

title: Calculate Population-Representative Averages — w_mean
code: # Load required packages and data library(dplyr) data(survey_data)  # Basic weighted usage survey_data %>% w_mean(age, weights = sampling_weight) #>  #> ── Weighted Mean Statistics ──────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> --- age --- #>  Variable weighted_mean Effective_N #>       age        50.514      2468.8 #>   # Multiple variables survey_data %>% w_mean(age, income, life_satisfaction, weights = sampling_weight) #>  #> ── Weighted Mean Statistics ──────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> --- age --- #>  Variable weighted_mean Effective_N #>       age        50.514      2468.8 #>  #> --- income --- #>  Variable weighted_mean Effective_N #>    income      3743.099      2158.9 #>  #> --- life_satisfaction --- #>           Variable weighted_mean Effective_N #>  life_satisfaction         3.625      2390.9 #>   # Grouped data survey_data %>% group_by(region) %>% w_mean(age, weights = sampling_weight) #>  #> ── Weighted Mean Statistics ──────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Group: region = East #> Warning: Unknown or uninitialised column: `Variable`. #>  #> Group: region = West #> Warning: Unknown or uninitialised column: `Variable`. #>   # In summarise context survey_data %>% summarise(mean_age = w_mean(age, weights = sampling_weight)) #> # A tibble: 1 × 1 #>   mean_age #>      <dbl> #> 1     50.5  # Unweighted (for comparison) survey_data %>% w_mean(age) #>  #> ── Mean Statistics ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> --- age --- #>  Variable  mean    N #>       age 50.55 2500 #>

title: Weighted Standard Deviation — w_sd

title: Weighted Standard Error — w_se
text: Calculate weighted standard error numeric variables, support grouped data multiple variables simultaneously. Formula: \(SE_w = s_w / \sqrt{V_1}\) \(s_w\) weighted SD \(V_1 = \sum w_i\).

title: mariposa 0.1.0
text: gamma() renamed goodman_gamma() avoid shadowing base::gamma(). function remains alias chi_square() works identically. S3 class names unified: removed _results suffix result classes (e.g., chi_square_results -> chi_square, t_test_results -> t_test). Class names now match function name created .

title: mariposa 0.1.0
text: Fixed namespace collisions triple-defined internal helper functions (.process_variables(), .process_weights(), .effective_n()). now defined helpers.R shared across functions. Fixed weighted variance/SD formula inconsistency. weighted calculations now use SPSS frequency weights formula: sum(w * (x - w_mean)^2) / (V1 - 1). Fixed Gamma ASE (asymptotic standard error) calculation. Replaced empirical magic-number formula correct ASE0 formula Agresti (2002). Fixed weighted Cohen’s d calculation t_test(). Previously multiplied values weights (x * w); now uses proper weighted means pooled weighted standard deviation. Fixed weighted kurtosis formula. Changed population excess kurtosis (m4/m2^2 - 3) SPSS Type 2 sample-corrected formula (G2 = ((n+1)*g2 + 6) * (n-1) / ((n-2)*(n-3))), matching SPSS output.

title: mariposa 0.1.0
text: Refactored 9 11 w_* functions use shared factory pattern (R/w_factory.R). Eliminated ~2,460 lines duplicated boilerplate (4,204 → 1,740 lines, -58.6%). w_modus w_quantile remain standalone due fundamentally different interfaces. Added 83 SPSS validation tests w_* functions across 4 scenarios (weighted/unweighted × grouped/ungrouped) test-weighted-statistics-spss-validation.R. Reduced memory usage: result objects now store columns needed post-hoc tests instead full input data frame. Unified print helper system: output formatting now uses print_helpers.R. Removed deprecated .print_header(), .print_border(), .get_border(), .print_group_header() helpers.R. Deduplicated t_test.R print methods: print.t_test_results print.t_test_result now share common implementation (~360 fewer lines). Added input validation: t_test(): validates conf.level 0 1 t_test(), oneway_anova(): validate selected variables numeric chi_square(): warns expected cell counts < 5 Migrated error handling stop()/warning() cli_abort()/cli_warn() structured messages, {.arg} {.var} markup, pluralization support. Added cli dependency professional user-facing messages print output. Added @family tags 24 exported functions cross-referencing documentation (families: descriptive, hypothesis_tests, correlation, posthoc, weighted_statistics). Added tests/testthat/helper-mariposa.R shared test utilities centralized SPSS validation tolerances. Migrated print_helpers.R infrastructure cli (cli_rule(), cli_bullets(), cli_h2()). Extended globals.R missing NSE variable declarations. Fixed “SURVEYSTAT” reference imports.R.
